PWFSLSmokePlots 0.4.3

  • Changelog

Create a Clock plot for a single monitor

Source: R/clockPlot.R
clockPlot.Rd

Create a "clock plot" showing PM2.5 data for a single day for the given monitors. A colored bar curves around in a clockwise manner with 12/4 of the bar colored for each hour of the local time day.

This function presents a simplified interface to clockPlotBase and collects common options into a set of named styles. Currently supported styles consist of a base style followed by one or more options separated by underscores.

The style base must be one of:

  • icon -- no annotations

  • full -- fully annotated

Style options include:

  • fan -- show nighttime shading

  • avg -- display center dot with yesterday average AQI color

The returned object may be further amended with `ggplot` elements.

clockPlot(ws_monitor, monitorID = NULL, startdate = NULL,
  enddate = NULL, style = "icon", centerColor = "black",
  labelScale = 1, title = "")

Arguments

ws_monitor

ws_monitor object.
monitorID

Monitor ID of interest.
startdate

Desired start date (integer or character in Ymd format or POSIXct).
enddate

Desired end date (integer or character in Ymd format or POSIXct).
style

Plot style as described below.
centerColor

Color used for the center of the circle.
labelScale

Scale factor applied to labels.
title

Optional title for the plot.

Value

A `ggplot` plot object with a "clock plot" for a single monitor.

Details

Dates are interpreted to be in monitor local time.

If either starttime or endtime is NULL, the plot will represent a single day. If the specified time range covers multiple days, the hourly bars will represent time-of-day averages while the center dot will show the average associated with the last day in the time range.

See also

clockPlotBase

Examples

mon <- PWFSLSmoke::Carmel_Valley
id <- mon$meta$monitorID[1]
start <- "2016-08-07"
end <- "2016-08-09"
icon <- clockPlot(mon, id, start, end, "icon",
                  title = "icon")
full <- clockPlot(mon, id, start, end, "full_fan_avg", "white",
                  title = "full_fan_avg")
gridExtra::grid.arrange(icon, full, nrow = 1)
